awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Core Support for Future Earth Capacity and Engagement in International Global Change Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports Future Earth to provide capacity building and engagement activities for US scientists working in global change research. Future Earth harnesses the insights and capacity of the global scientific community to address global problems and ensures that the results of this work extend beyond academic communities and impact broader decision processes. Future Earth efforts are based on the recognition that modern sustainability challenges require coordinated research efforts bringing together the world's best researchers in the natural, social, behavioral, and engineering sciences, and connecting these researchers with the needs and capacities embedded within a wide range of stakeholder institutions and communities. Future Earth’s global initiatives, include a flagship capacity building program (Earth Leadership Program), far reaching communications products (Anthropocene Magazine), and strong collaborative data-platforms.

By elevating the spread and impact of scientific results and connecting these results with constituencies in business, government, and civil society, Future Earth’s work supports better decision making around the world. This work also connects US researchers with a vast and rapidly growing network of leading international scholars in global change research and provides direct access to new knowledge and initiatives. Much of this work is supported through strategic communications that extends the reach of sustainability science published around the world, and delivers the very best global science in the right format, and at the correct time, to shape global outcomes. This project will include the publication of the award-winning Anthropocene Magazine which consistently brings the very best sustainability science to the broadest possible audience around the world, and the establishment of the Sustainability Research and Innovation Congress - the first global convening supporting global connections between sustainability science and innovation communities around the world on an annual basis. Finally, Future Earth will continue leading the Earth Leadership Program, which builds on the 20 years of success of the Leopold Leadership Program, and focuses on training diverse cohorts of high-impact mid-career scientists to reach beyond their disciplinary expertise to become sustainability science leaders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Future Earth is a global network organization advancing transdisciplinary and sustainability science. The US Global Secretariat Hub (US Hub) is one of the nine offices of Future Earth's distributed global Secretariat, and it leads several key functions, ranging from global communications, IT and finance, to coordination of the national committees and global research networks. In addition, the US Hub leads two rapidly growing international programs: the Sustainability Research and Innovation Congress (SRI) and the Anthropocene Magazine.

 

This project includes activities in four work areas: 1) Communication and Engagement; 2) Research Leadership and Capacity; 3) Convening and Connecting Communities; and 4) Building a More Global Network.

 

Communication and Engagement:

The Future Earth US Hub has been responsible for the full suite of internal and external communications work within Future Earth. This work ranged from the production of the Future Earth annual report and monthly newsletter that reaches almost 9,000 people, to the production of sustainability science news and commentary on the Future Earth website, and the management of Future Earth's growing social media channels. The communications team also worked directly with Future Earth's Global Research Networks to launch their highest impact research reports and supported the development of critical interventions and synthesis products from the global research community at and around major global conventions. In addition, the Future Earth US Hub produced the Anthropocene Magazine, Future Earth's premier independent science magazine, which continued to grow at an impressive pace, adding 800-1,000 new subscribers every month. Over 44,000 subscribers have now signed up for two weekly Anthropocene newsletters. Finally, the Future Earth US Hub supported and oversaw the communications of the Sustainability Research and Innovation Congress (SRI). 

 

Research Leadership Capacity:

The Future Earth US Hub supported research leadership capacity building in various ways. SRI offered several scholarships and training opportunities for early career researchers from all over the world. During this grant period, Future Earth's Earth Leadership Program was also reframed to embrace a broader variety of capacity building activities - a process that still continues. 

 

Convening and Connecting Communities:

The US Hub leads the SRI series, which is the world's largest annual event focused on sustainability science and transdisciplinary research. This global gathering brings together leading professionals in global change and sustainability science and offers a truly transdisciplinary platform for action-forward yet science-informed engagement. During this grant period, the US Hub delivered SRI2022 in South Africa, bringing together over 1500 participants from more than 100 countries for an inclusive hybrid event, and prepared for SRI2023, which will take place in Panama in June 2023 and is expected to convene an even larger in-person audience. SRI, which is a collaboration with the Belmont Forum, continues to innovate on its program of over 200 sessions (including satellite events that significantly increase the geographic reach of the event) and attracting new participants, partners and sponsors, making the event increasingly transdisciplinary, diverse and engaging. The Hub is already working with the hosts of SRI2024 and SRI2025 and developing a long-term vision and strategy to further grow the impact of the Congress.

 

4) Building a More Global Network: 

The US Hub continues to lead Future Earth's global coordination work, from managing global finances to coordinating the Governing Council, Assembly and Directors Council meetings. The Hub also manages global IT and finances.
